body: @jerrypeng If you submit the pulsar-aws-nar-0.0.1.nar without specifying a classname, then the sink/source configured in the pulsar-io.yaml file will be used. You can think of that as the "default" connectors, that can be overridden by the className property.
@david-streamlio ok that sounds good to me. Just making sure all code paths are covered.
@david-streamlio please revert back the change in pulsar_tools_env.sh and I think we are good to go. Thanks!

@ofaz I have a fix up for this issue:

https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3684

in the mean time, to side step this issue, you can enable batching in your producer:

```
producer = client.create_producer(PULSAR_TOPIC,                             schema=JsonSchema(SimpleRecord)), batching_enabled=True)
```

run java8 tests
run integration tests
@srkukarni PR looks good.  Can we add a unit test for this?
@sijie @ivankelly @jiazhai can you please take look as this prevents running functions on MacOS using python2

> I don't think we should change the default here. There is already a default mechanism implemented: 

Correct. If necessary we just need to have something like: `Math.min(4, 2 * Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors())`

@jerrypeng @srkukarni I am not able to reproduce what your problem at my mac using the 4.9.0 bookkeeper client. my mac is Mojave 10.14. 

do you have a different grpc proto3 installed? the stack trace shows it is related to proto3. Also I am not sure what does `2.3.0.post1` mean here. It doesn't seem to be an official release.
2.3.0.post1 is official release it's an update to 2.3.0

@sijie @srkukarni after I updated protobuf to the latest version for python2, I didn't get the error anymore:

```
Jerrys-MacBook-Pro:incubator-pulsar jerrypeng$ pip install protobuf --upgrade
Collecting protobuf
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/2b/2b/d51219eb18a140836cb656053e5408cd18fd752217ff73ca596204cd3183/protobuf-3.6.1-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_6_intel.macosx_10_9_intel.macosx_10_9_x86_64.macosx_10_10_intel.macosx_10_10_x86_64.whl

Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: six>=1.9 in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages (from protobuf) (1.11.0)

>>> import bookkeeper.admin

```
@sijie I guess this could be merged  unless you think there should be something else that should be done.
@jerrypeng maybe we can set the version of protobuf to be 3.6.1

https://pypi.org/project/protobuf/

that's the latest version so it should fine to take a dependency on it.

@rdhabalia it seems that you didn't reply to my comment. this PR removed settings from configurations. these should be well thought and also well documented before merging this PR. otherwise it will cause confusions when people upgraded pulsar

- This problem seems likely to occur in the following situations:
  - Consumer creation and closing are repeated many times in parallel using the WebSocket API
  - The topic is partitioned
  - The subscription type is Shared
- This problem no longer occurs (or has become difficult to occur) when I revert https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/2785

We have something similar:

`text format parsing error in line 189: second TYPE line for metric name "pulsar_subscriptions_count", or TYPE reported after samples`

When doing a port forward on my pod:
`kubectl port-forward   $(kubectl get pods -l component=broker -o jsonpath='{.items[*].metadata.name}') 8080`

I can see on [http://localhost:8080/metrics/](http://localhost:8080/metrics/).

Some of the metrics like `pulsar_subscriptions_count` are duplicated (one by default and one for each namespace).

I wrote a simple test code of caffeine used for ZK cache:
https://gist.github.com/massakam/3e15f0bad0260b17382dbc4bc785aa25#file-caffeinetest-java

Executing this code often results in the following:
https://gist.github.com/massakam/3e15f0bad0260b17382dbc4bc785aa25#file-result-sh

In this case, `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3` slept for 10 seconds.

> 22:03:10.183 [0] [ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3] [INFO] Sleeping 10 sec...

Then, these three processes were completed about 10 seconds after the other processes were completed. Even though there were five threads named `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-x`, threads other than `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3` were were idle.

> 22:03:20.186 [3] [ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3] [INFO] key: 6, value: val6
> 22:03:20.186 [9] [ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3] [INFO] key: 6, value: val6
> 22:03:20.186 [1] [ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-3] [INFO] key: 6, value: val6

I think that the same thing as this is happening in broker.

1. A thread `pulsar-io-x-x` locks a `PersistentSubscription` object to add a consumer.
2. In order to add the consumer, it is necessary to refer to `max_consumers_per_topic` included in the policy of the namespace, and it is assumed that a thread `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-x` is in charge of that.
3. However, suppose that thread `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-x` tries to add another consumer to the same subscription of the same topic before the process 2.
4. 3 does not complete as the `PersistentSubscription` object is locked. 2 also does not complete as the thread `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-x` remains blocked.

What do you think about the above assumption?
That seems to be the right approach to make sure that protobuf is atleast 3.6.1

run java8 tests
run integration tests

> how about calling `delayedAck` instead `negativeAck`? 

This is not delaying the ack (which is something we already have as an internal optimization, see https://pulsar.apache.org/api/client/org/apache/pulsar/client/api/ConsumerBuilder.html#acknowledgmentGroupTime-long-java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit- ). 

Rather this is signaling the failure to process. After the timeout since the nack is called, the message will not be automatically acked, but rather re-delivered.

Also see these links for terminology context: 
 * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acknowledgement_(data_networks)
 * https://www.rabbitmq.com/nack.html

Hi! I really like this feature :+1: !! just a small suggestion around `NegativeAcksTracker` class.
What about using `ConcurrentHashSet` for 'nackedMessages' field and `AtomicReference` for 'timeout' field instead of using `synchronized` methods?

@sijie Oops..I missed to check your comment.
> otherwise it will cause confusions when people upgraded pulsar

This configuration was added because this was an experimental feature earlier and this config can avoid any conflict between persistent and np topic. However, this feature is now, matured enough and we know that np topic will not have any impact with persistent topic if they exist together into the same broker.

> these should be well thought and also well documented before merging this PR.

This PR should not have any -ve impact though we can document it. We already have issue created at #596. Do you think we should document it in somewhere in code or website?
@rdhabalia Since this is not a fix or a trivial change, I'd move this to 2.4.0 rather than 2.3.1

@skyrocknroll 
> is this issue related to this #3348 ?

I don't see any specific change in #3348 which can cause this issue. it seems broker is not able to fetch topics-list from other broker that owns specific bundle and then it's timing out. I tried to start pulsar cluster with 3 brokers and I am able to get successful response for` ./pulsar-admin non-persistent list public/default`

Do you see any errors at broker log? or can you share the thread-dump of the broker which actually owns the topic?

> Consumer creation and closing are repeated many times in parallel using the WebSocket API

yes, this happens when cache gets expired (after 5 mins) and at the same time many, threads tries to access the same key from the cache (so, it mainly occurs while adding-consumer which requires to to access global-zk cache). In our case, one of the client was keep disconnecting and creating new consumers and broker was going into deadlock state with in 10-20 mins.

> also does not complete as the thread `ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-x` remains blocked.

Hmm..ok, so, should we process zk-cache callback into separate external executor rather using default `ForkJoinPool` thread executor that also used by cache internally.?

I have created PR #3708 with the change so, will you be able to verify if this patch fixes the issue.

@massakam 
I think you are right. thread-dump shows the same deadlock condition where
1. `pulsar-io` takes lock on `PersistentSubscription's` synchronized method and waiting for zk response
2. `ForkJoinPool` gets value from zk and same thread tries to access same lock taken by `pulsar-io` thread in `PersistentSubscription`. so, `ForkJoinPool-thread` couldn't complete and can't serve further zk-cache request. and the same time pulsar-io threads are waiting for zk-cache respinse.

I think running zk-cache callback into OrderedExecutor might not be the good idea because `orderedExecutor-thread` calls zk-cache and if callback gets executed into the same executor then it will again cause the deadlock. So, have to figure out better solution here.
